intro: Ophiorrhiza aureolina, commonly known as the golden mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant that belongs to the family Rubiaceae. It is native to Southeast Asia, including regions such as India, Indonesia, and the Philippines. The plant has small, elliptical leaves that are usually arranged in pairs along the stems. It produces yellowish-white flowers that are clustered in inflorescences, followed by small, fleshy berries. Ophiorrhiza aureolina is often found growing on the branches of host trees, relying on them for some of its nutritional needs.
